content.description:
Perhaps to second most strinking line at this cliff, the first one being Quintessence.

Start on an easy crack with good feet to just underneath a slopy ledge. Gain that ledge doing a tricky mantle and move right to get established at the bottom of a left facing openbook. Layback this to a tiny ledge and climb some wider cracks to the horizontals and to some good stemming stances. Face climb into the corner (crux) making strenous moves with hard to place pros. Use a good hold to finish on a thin section of face that leads to a tree-ledge with a 2-bolt anchor.

Classic trad test-piece!

This is the left facing overhanging dihedral 15-20 ft to the left of the Quintessence crack.Â 
Microcams to Camalot 3, doubles to 0.75 and nuts. Offset cams were nice to have in the openbook and below it.

What an esthetic line on sharp rock! 
  
 The start can be tricky to protect. Don't plug the pods with cams, place small nuts instead. I think this section could be rated PG-13.  
  
 Start on a shallow block underneath a right facing slightly right leaning dihedral. Follow the dihedral to an overhang to a small roof and move left into a steep hand and fist crack. Follow the crack to an anchor.


You really can't miss the splitter crack it is visible from the parking lot.

to Camalot #3 with some small nuts. Fixed anchor.

That is the first visible area encountered while driving/approaching the cliff. It is located to the very rightside of the cliff. This area and its very prominent spliter crack "Quintessence" is visible from the main parking lot. 
  
 This area faces the south-west direction and sun hits the routes around 11am. Early morning climbing are advised in the summer time. In late fall, climbing conditions might be at there best.
